chapters.name: Chloe Wofford: Before the Name (1931-1970)
topics: Who was Toni Morrison before she became the most important American novelist of the 20th century — born Chloe Ardelia Wofford in Lorain, Ohio, the granddaughter of sharecroppers who fled the South, educated at Howard University and Cornell, a single mother of two who wrote novels before dawn while working as a textbook editor?

What was Lorain, Ohio — a multiethnic steel town where Black families lived alongside Italians, Greeks, and Mexicans — and how did growing up in an integrated working-class community rather than the segregated South shape Morrison's distinctive perspective on race in America?

How did Morrison's years at Howard University (1949-1953) — studying English, joining a theater troupe that toured the Deep South, encountering segregation firsthand — and Cornell (MA, 1955, thesis on Faulkner and Woolf) prepare her intellectually for the novels she would write?

How did Morrison work as an editor at Random House (1967-1983) — championing Toni Cade Bambara, Gayl Jones, Angela Davis, and Muhammad Ali, editing 'The Black Book' (a scrapbook of African American history) — quietly reshaping American publishing while building her own literary career?

How did 'The Bluest Eye' (1970) — the story of Pecola Breedlove, a Black girl who prays for blue eyes — establish Morrison's project: centering Black female experience, refusing to explain Black culture to white readers, insisting that Black interiority was worthy of the highest literary art?

chapters.name: The Major Novels (1973-1987)
topics: What made 'Sula' (1973) distinctive — the story of two Black women whose friendship defies every convention of their community, a novel that refuses to judge its morally ambiguous protagonist — and why did Morrison insist that Black female friendship was a subject worthy of serious literature?

How did 'Song of Solomon' (1977) become her breakthrough — a multigenerational epic about Milkman Dead's search for identity, the first novel by a Black writer selected for the Book-of-the-Month Club since Richard Wright — proving that 'difficult' literature could reach a mass audience?

What did 'Tar Baby' (1981) accomplish — setting the story on a Caribbean island, examining colorism and class within Black communities, confronting the tensions between assimilation and cultural authenticity — and why was this her most controversial novel among Black readers?

What is 'Beloved' (1987) — based on the true story of Margaret Garner, an enslaved woman who killed her daughter rather than let her be returned to slavery — and why is this novel, which makes the reader feel the horror of slavery in their body, considered one of the greatest American novels ever written?

Why did 48 Black writers and critics sign a letter protesting when 'Beloved' was passed over for the National Book Award (1987) — calling it a 'deliberate slight' — and how did the Pulitzer Prize that followed (1988) confirm Morrison's standing as America's most important living novelist?

chapters.name: The Nobel and the National Voice (1988-2003)
topics: Why did Morrison win the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1993 — 'who in novels characterized by visionary force and poetic import, gives life to an essential aspect of American reality' — becoming the first Black woman and only the eighth woman to receive the honor?

What was Morrison's Nobel lecture — a meditation on the power and responsibility of language, the story of an old blind woman challenged by children to prove her wisdom — and why is this lecture itself considered a masterpiece of American prose?

How did Morrison's later novels — 'Jazz' (1992, Harlem in the 1920s), 'Paradise' (1997, an all-Black Oklahoma town), 'Love' (2003) — extend her exploration of how Black communities build, sustain, and sometimes destroy themselves?

What was Morrison's role as a public intellectual — her essays on race and American identity, her response calling Bill Clinton 'the first Black president,' her commentary on the O.J. Simpson trial and the Clarence Thomas hearings — and how did she use her authority to insist that America confront its racial history?

How did Morrison's appointment to Princeton University (1989-2006) — the first Black woman to hold a named chair at an Ivy League university — transform her influence from literary to institutional, shaping a generation of writers, scholars, and thinkers?

chapters.name: The Craft: How Morrison Wrote
topics: What was Morrison's writing process — rising at 4 AM, writing before dawn, composing in longhand, revising obsessively — and why did she insist that writing was work, not inspiration, that 'if you waited for inspiration you'd never write a line'?

How did Morrison use language — sentences that function like music, a narrative voice that shifts between intimate and mythic, dialogue that captures speech patterns without condescending to dialect — and why did she consider the sound of her prose as important as its meaning?

What was Morrison's relationship to the Western literary canon — her debt to Faulkner's narrative complexity, her rejection of Hemingway's stripped-down prose, her insistence that Black literary traditions (oral storytelling, call-and-response, the blues) were equally sophisticated?

How did Morrison handle the 'white gaze' — refusing to describe Black characters through white eyes, never making whiteness the default against which Blackness is measured, writing as if white readers either kept up or didn't — and why was this refusal itself a political act?

What did Morrison mean when she said her project was 'to write the books I wanted to read' — filling the gaps in American literature where Black women's stories should have been, treating slavery not as historical backdrop but as lived trauma that echoes through generations?

chapters.name: Legacy: The Books That Changed What American Literature Could Be
topics: How did Morrison's final novels — 'A Mercy' (2008, exploring race before American slavery codified it), 'Home' (2012, a Korean War veteran's return), 'God Help the Child' (2015, colorism and childhood trauma) — continue to expand her investigation of race, memory, and belonging?

What is Morrison's legacy after her death on August 5, 2019 — the demonstration that Black experience is universal experience, that literary excellence and political urgency are not opposites, and that the American novel is incomplete without the voices it spent centuries silencing?

How has Morrison influenced subsequent writers — Jesmyn Ward, Colson Whitehead, Tayari Jones, Brit Bennett — and why is the 'post-Morrison' generation of Black novelists both indebted to her and determined to move beyond her?

Why is 'Beloved' consistently ranked among the greatest novels of all time — the New York Times named it the best American novel of the past 25 years (2006), it appears on virtually every canonical list — and what makes a novel about one woman's experience of slavery a universal statement about memory, guilt, and survival?

What did Morrison prove — that a Black woman from a steel town in Ohio could become the greatest American novelist of her era, that refusing to compromise literary vision for accessibility or palatability is not a limitation but a strategy, and that the stories America most needs to hear are the ones it has tried hardest to silence?
